The Kings of Leon

Album - Mechanical Bull

Critic Reviews

82

Clash

I have always loved albums that give me a summer feeling, and this is no exception. Mechanical Bull really gives me the feeling like I'm in some kind of American coast city where it's super hot outside and I'm walking along the beach. They really nailed the ‘’summer rock’’ production style on here. I don't even know if it's intentional, but I really dig it. . Usually the more chill out or so-called ‘’Ballads’’ would bring an alt-rock album down to me, but I actually really enjoy the slow songs on here, as they still have that whole summer vibe that I was talking about earlier. I also feel like this is the album where Caleb’s voice is at its best, love his vocals on this.

If you don't like pure uncut dreamy summer cock rock, then this isn't for you. But personally, I can't wait till it's summer in my country and vibe with this even more. I would also love to see KOL perform at a festival in summer and hear songs like Supersoaker and Wait For Me live.

86

Rolling Stone

Kings of Leon is one of those bands that have a lot of songs I enjoy, but they're not much of an 'album band' and I can understand why people who dislike them (outside the 'first 3 good everything after bad' crowd which I've never understood). That being said, this is a very consistent and cohesive album and probably their best in my opinion; a big improvement over Come Around Sundown which is mediocre.

Supersoaker is my favourite KOL songs; it may be one of their poppiest but it's so catchy and charmingly suggestive and features some of Jared's best bass grooves. Rock City is solid, but I think I could go without hearing Caleb bellowing "I could shake it like a woman". Don't Matter is a straight-up banger and one of the band's heaviest, boldest and all-in-all best songs with a fantastic solo from Matthew.

78

Pitchfork

Kings of Leon have spent the past five years sounding over-polished and lacking real ideas. Still, their new album provides some hope. Mechanical Bull is looser, more raw and more gospel, even more soulful than recent efforts. It takes moments to breathe, not belting your ears with a high sonic force. Comedown Story is touching, "I’d walk a mile in your shoes/Now I’m a mile away/And I’ve got your shoes” and Supersoaker is ingrained with a harsher edge and more visceral impact than some of the plodding songs found on 2010’s Come Around Sundown. Kings of Leon sound a bit better.
